development.title: How does mission development happen?
development.description: During the Space Challenge, students experience all stages of a real mission. They start by defining a problem and the satellite's objective, plan how it will operate and what data it will collect, program their sensors on an educational platform, and perform tests and simulations. The project culminates in the launch of a PocketQube into orbit, allowing students to monitor its operation and analyze real data. Throughout the process, they develop technical skills, scientific thinking, teamwork, and a vision for the future in the space field.

mission1.name: UAI-SAT
mission1.description:
UaiSat is a PocketQube space equipment, shaped as a 5 cm cube on each side. Besides being the first from Minas Gerais state, it is the first PocketQube developed by a Brazilian university and launched into space. It will orbit the planet at an average altitude of 500 to 600 km, with an expected lifespan of 2 years.

**Mission Objective**

UaiSat's main mission is to validate technology in orbit in addition to collecting data on agriculture and other productive sectors in Minas Gerais, such as soil data, temperature, humidity, among others. It will also monitor lightning and storms, using technology developed in partnership with the National Institute for Space Research (INPE). The main mission is the validation of technology in the space environment.

mission2.name: SARI-1
mission2.description:
The mission is part of a project developed by university students, which aims to use the satellite to connect IoT sensors in Brazil and Saudi Arabia. The satellite is equipped with a payload consisting of an SD card to store data received from ground stations and a radio system dedicated to transmitting and relaying collected information. By combining accessible space technology and practical application, the project offers students practical experience in space engineering, from development to mission operation.

**Mission Objective**

The objective of this mission is to connect a network of IoT sensors through a picosatellite developed by students, providing data to assist the population while promoting technical training for those involved in applied space engineering.

mission3.name: Galaxy Explorer
mission3.description:
Galaxy Explorer aims to perform radiation measurements and connect to IoT sensors in Brazil. The Radio Payload consists of a Store and Forward system in which the satellite is able to receive messages from ground transmitters, store them, and transmit them when flying over a ground station. The mission also carries a radiation sensor capable of measuring Alpha and Beta radiation. This sensor is especially interesting because it was developed nationally to be low-cost and relatively accurate. This is possible using photodiodes.

**Mission Objective**

Galaxy Explorer is a technological mission that aims to conduct radiation measurement experiments using low-cost photodiode-based sensors. The mission will also demonstrate the in-orbit operation of a 1P PocketQube platform developed in Brazil in a partnership between All2Space and entrepreneur Kevin Tang Xilai.

about.title: The values that take us to space
about.description: Ideia Space offers practical educational journeys that connect schools and students to real space missions. With a 'hands-on' methodology, we empower young people to design, assemble and operate PocketQubes, transforming school experience into technical skills and entrepreneurial spirit - creating a direct bridge between basic education and the space industry.
about.historyDescription: Ideia Space was born in Brasília with the purpose of transforming how the educational sector connects with space technology. The company emerged from a common vision: to make space more accessible, educationally relevant and closer to students' reality. Combining innovation, science and education, Ideia Space develops practical experiences that bring schools and institutions closer to the space ecosystem, promoting learning through real projects, educational missions and applied technologies. Its mission is to train the next generation of space professionals and enthusiasts, boosting Brazilian leadership in the global space scenario. Its values are guided by innovation, collaboration, technical excellence and commitment to transformative education.

deployer.title: Deployer System
deployer.description:

• Capacity: Multiple PocketQubes
• Mechanism: Spring ejection
• Compatibility: PocketQube standard
• Safety: Redundant locking system

whySpaceChallenge.description: The Space Challenge is Ideia Space's practical educational journey that connects students from Middle School to Higher Education to a real space mission. Through interdisciplinary challenges and hands-on projects, students develop skills in science, technology, engineering and teamwork, while designing, programming and operating an educational satellite. More than learning about space, they become part of it — acquiring technical skills, critical thinking and future vision aligned with the demands of the new space economy.
whySpaceChallenge.cardDescription: An educational journey that transforms students into protagonists of space exploration, developing essential skills for the future.

howItWorks.title: How does it work?
howItWorks.description: The Space Challenge is structured in three progressive phases that lead students from initial understanding of the space sector to the concrete experience of designing and monitoring the launch of a real orbital satellite. Each phase was designed to develop technical skills, systemic thinking and student leadership in a challenging and highly applied environment.

phase1.title: Phase 1: Space Mission Concept and Design
phase1.description: Students learn the fundamentals of space missions, understand how objectives, orbits and payloads influence the project, and define the purpose of the mission their team will develop.

phase2.title: Phase 2: Project Concept and Design
phase2.description: Based on the mission, students use the Educational Satellite Kit to understand a satellite's subsystems and design the main functionalities of the orbital model, connecting technical decisions to the defined purpose.

phase3.title: Phase 3: Orbital Satellite and Launch
phase3.description: Selected teams develop, integrate and test the orbital satellite. After final preparation, the satellite is sent to the launch vehicle and placed in orbit, where students monitor its real operation.

whatIsChallenge.title: What is the Space Challenge?
whatIsChallenge.description: It is a Space Mission project competition aimed at high school students (14 to 18 years old). The project is designed for one year and impacts different groups of students in progressive stages:

methodology.title: Our Methodology: Learning by Doing
methodology.description: Our philosophy is based on Project-Based Learning (PBL) and the "Hands On" concept. The Space Challenge is structured in a 5-step pedagogical path:

conceive.title: Conceive
conceive.description: Students define the scope and objectives of the mission. They answer: 'What problem will my mission solve?'.

design.title: Design
design.description: Teams detail what the space mission will be like and what resources will be needed.

build.title: Build
build.description: Students explore the satellite development kit (SMT) and bring the mission to life.

launch.title: Launch
launch.description: Selected students build the orbital satellite, conduct tests, and prepare it for launch.

apply.title: Apply
apply.description: With the satellite in orbit, students use its data to solve the problem identified in the mission conception.

preChallenge.title: Pre-Challenge
preChallenge.description: Project organization, rule definition, school selection and teacher training.

phase1.title: Phase 1: Conception
phase1.description: Course begins for 500 students. Focus on problem analysis and space mission conception (MCR).

phase2.title: Phase 2: Design
phase2.description: Students receive SMT Kits. Final project presentation (PDR) and selection of best teams.

phase3.title: Phase 3: Construction
phase3.description: The 30 selected students build the PocketQube satellite. Testing, delivery and orbit insertion.

postChallenge.title: Post-Challenge
postChallenge.description: With the satellite in orbit, Ideia Space collects data and shares it with institutions.
